articles.headline: Debt Burden Lifting, Consumers Open Wallets a Crack
articles.snippet: Household financial obligations, relative to income, have declined to levels not seen in years, helping add to consumer optimism.
articles.abstract: Household financial obligations, relative to income, have declined to levels not seen in years, helping add to consumer optimism.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bursting of the real estate bubble and the ensuing credit crisis forced American consumers to do something that they had little experience in trying: reduce their debt.

articles.headline: With Vote Days Away, Outlook for Sarkozy Dims
articles.snippet: Nicolas Sarkozy could be the first one-term French president since 1981, with the first round of voting scheduled for Sunday.
articles.abstract: Nicolas Sarkozy could be the first one-term French president since 1981, with the first round of voting scheduled for Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The candidate — energetic, bold, indefatigable — is sure he will win, aides say, as he pulls energy from his big crowds.

articles.headline: A Tarnished Standing for Europe
articles.snippet: European problems will be at the forefront of discussions this weekend at the spring meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
articles.abstract: European problems will be at the forefront of discussions this weekend at the spring meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Europeans may discover this week that the debt crisis is not only threatening the euro zone economy and the integrity of the common currency, but also diminishing Europe’s influence in world affairs.
articles.byline: By Annie Lowrey and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: New District Maps Toughen Democrats’ Race for House
articles.snippet: Many Democrats have decided to retire rather than risk defeat in newly configured House districts, leaving the districts in play or solidly Republican.
articles.abstract: Many Democrats have decided to retire rather than risk defeat in newly configured House districts, leaving the districts in play or solidly Republican.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.C. — Representative Larry Kissell slid into a diner booth here and sought to explain — with no small amount of irritation, since he has apparently been asked many times — his decision to run in his newly configured House district, in contrast to two fellow North Carolina Democrats who retired rather than risk defeat in districts reshaped by Republicans.

articles.headline: Rising Fears That Recovery May Once More Be Faltering
articles.snippet: Global finance leaders are meeting in Washington to discuss oil prices, unemployment and other issues putting a cloud over the global economic picture.
articles.abstract: Global finance leaders are meeting in Washington to discuss oil prices, unemployment and other issues putting a cloud over the global economic picture.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some of the same spoilers that interrupted the recovery in 2010 and 2011 have emerged again, raising fears that the winter’s economic strength might dissipate in the spring.

articles.headline: I.M.F. Adds $430 Billion in Emergency Lending Ability
articles.snippet: The International Monetary Fund’s extra lending capacity could be used if the euro zone crisis worsens or global financial conditions deteriorate.
articles.abstract: The International Monetary Fund’s extra lending capacity could be used if the euro zone crisis worsens or global financial conditions deteriorate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund has raised at least $430 billion in extra lending capacity to be used if the euro zone crisis worsens or global financial conditions deteriorate, it said Friday afternoon.

articles.headline: In One Man’s Return, the Tax Code’s Unfairness
articles.snippet: A reporter’s income in 2011 was higher than it was in 2010. Yet his tax rate went down. Wasn’t the opposite supposed to happen?
articles.abstract: A reporter’s income in 2011 was higher than it was in 2010. Yet his tax rate went down. Wasn’t the opposite supposed to happen?
articles.lead_paragraph: Like most Americans (though not Mitt Romney, who got an extension), I filed my 2011 tax returns this week and paid my five layers of income tax: federal, state, local, self-employed and something called the metropolitan commuter tax (even though I live in New York City and don’t commute). When I first looked at the returns, I was incredulous.

articles.headline: Bias Law Used to Move a Man Off Death Row
articles.snippet: A North Carolina judge concluded that bias played a part in a 1994 sentence, a ruling likely to influence the nation’s discussion of capital punishment.
articles.abstract: A North Carolina judge concluded that bias played a part in a 1994 sentence, a ruling likely to influence the nation’s discussion of capital punishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C. — Concluding that racial bias played a significant factor in a death sentence here 18 years ago, a judge on Friday ordered that it be changed to life in prison without parole, the first such decision under North Carolina’s controversial Racial Justice Act.
